awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Computational Gravitational-Wave Science and Education in the Era of First Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
A century after Einstein predicted their existence, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) discovered gravitational waves--ripples of warped space and time---from a pair of merging black holes. Imminent discoveries in the dawning era of gravitational-wave astronomy could dramatically change our understanding of the universe. This project will help scientists observe as many gravitational waves as possible while learning as much as possible about the waves' sources. Using supercomputers, the PI and students will calculate the gravitational waves from merging black holes and neutron stars, to expedite and respond to LIGO's observations; they will also model the most important source of noise limiting LIGO's reach. By teaching students from local community colleges about supercomputing and gravitational-wave science, the PI and students will help train the next generation of America's STEM workforce. This project will have a substantial positive impact on students from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM, who will learn transferable skills in research and computing while playing important roles in gravitational-wave science. The PI and student researchers will broadly disseminate their results to other scientists and the public.

This award supports an integrated research and education program at California State University, Fullerton. The PI and students will simulate merging black holes and neutron stars, including those with rapid black-hole spins. They will use results from these simulations to help gravitational-wave astronomers extract the most interesting and surprising scientific results from LIGO's observations, including properties of merging black holes and tests of general relativity under the most extreme conditions. The PI and students will also model thermal noise in gravitational-wave detector optics, leveraging the sophisticated techniques used in numerical relativity to model merging black holes. This will help improve the thermal noise of high precision measurements and will increase gravitational-wave detectors' reach and sensitivity to properties of observed gravitational waves. The PI and students will integrate methods and results from their research into an annual, week-long workshop, where STEM majors from local community colleges will gain hands-on experience using a high-performance computing cluster to simulate and visualize merging black holes.

por.por_cntn:
Gravitational waves are ripples of warped space and time that travel through the universe at the speed of light.  A century after Einstein predicted their existence, the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory ignited the era of gravitational-wave astronomy with the discovery of gravitational waves passing through Earth. The waves were created when two black holes collided and merged, about a billion light years away from Earth. 

LIGO has since observed dozens of gravitational waves from merging black holes and neutron stars. Because these waves carry information about the cataclysmic events that generate them, such as colliding black holes and neutron stars, they offer a window into the laws of physics under the most extreme conditions. But accessing that information is only possible with supercomputer calculations that model the waves and their sources, so that gravitational-wave astronomers can compare the theoretical models with the observed waves.

This award supported and integrated research and education program at Cal State University, Fullerton, focusing on supercomputer calculations to model gravitational-wave sources. The award enabled the PI and his research group to play a leading role in a major expansion of the Simulating eXtreme Spacetimes (SXS) Collaboration's catalog of numerical-relativity waveforms for merging black holes. They used the Spectral Einstein Code to calculate the curved spacetime and emitted gravitational waves for dozens of different merging black holes, sharing the results with the SXS Collaboration and the broader scientific community. These calculations are helping others to develop approximate models needed to infer the nature of observed gravitational waves' sources. Together with colleagues in the SXS Collaboration, they used some of these calculations to explore how well LIGO could infer the properties of merging black holes that are rapidly spinning or spinning when the axes of the black holes' spins and orbit all lie in a flat, two-dimensional plane. 

The PI and his group also contributed to the development of SpECTRE, a new, open-source numerical-relativity code that aims to achieve the tremendous gains in accuracy that the next decade's gravitational-wave observatories will need. SpECTRE will do this by leveraging novel techniques to take full advantage of the large supercomputers expected in the 2030s. The PI and his group played a major role in enabling and completing SpECTRE's first calculations of pairs of merging black holes. They also leveraged the techniques of numerical relativity to model the most important noise source for LIGO: coating thermal noise (noise caused by the random thermal motion of the atoms in LIGO's mirrors' reflective coatings). In particular, they found that using SpECTRE's numerical techniques (including a "discontinuous Galerkin method") yielded much more accurate and efficient thermal-noise calculations than their earlier approach using more conventional approach (based on a "finite-element method").

The award enabled the PI to mentor more than a dozen undergraduate and master's students, including many students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science. Nine of these students are now pursuing doctoral study in physics or astronomy, and three are NSF Graduate Research Fellows. Through their research experience, every student in the PI's group gained skills that they will take with them into their future STEM careers, including experience programming in Python and C++, performing supercomputer calculations, and analyzing and visualizing the results of these simulations.

Dozens of community college students participated in annual workshops on high-performance computing, gravitational waves, and undergraduate research opportunities. They learned orders of magnitude in computing, learned to write Python programs that can calculate in parallel (using all of the cores available on a computer, instead of just one core at a time), and used the Spectral Einstein Code to calculate and visualize brief calculations of black holes that fall together head-on and merge. The workshop featured examples of research from the PI's group, especially results and visualizations from students. Undergraduate and master's students in the PI's research group and colleagues from other institutions presented their research at the workshop, and they discussed with participants their experience and advice about undergraduate research opportunities and transferring to a four-year institution as a STEM major. Some students transferred to Cal State Fullerton following this workshop, including one student who joined the PI's group, graduated with a B.S. in physics, and is now pursuing his Ph.D. in physics at Washington State University as a Department of Energy Computational Science Graduate Fellow.

The PI and members of his group shared the excitement of gravitational-wave astronomy with other scientists and with the public. They presented their work to K-12 students and to the public, spoke at national and international scientific meetings, and created visualizations of merging black holes featured in the national and international media.
